div2.head: Regional Dialects A
div2.u: I've had no trouble yet when I have been in New England. I would have to listen to it and get into the habit of—of remembering to use their own terms, their own diction, but there was no difficulty about understanding what they meant.

Some of—some of us were talking about Thomas Wolfe this morning, and we were under the impression—though I don't know that anyone has studied it closely—that he's very good at handling New England dialect and New York dialect as well as his native southern, so perhaps you could.
Well, you have dealt with English speech in—in some of your short stories and French speech in A Fable, it seems to me.

div2.head: Whupped v Whipped
div2.u: I don't mean to be nitpicking. I'm really asking these questions for my own information. But another time you have Wash say "whupped" for the—for "whipped." Wouldn't the colonel have said "whupped" too? And if so, why did you give Wash the spelling—?

Probably not. The colonel wouldn't have said "whupped." He—by—by nature, he might've—have said "whupped," but he had associated with gentle folk and other plantation owners long enough to have said "whipped" without knowing he was changing his speech. But Wash would still have said "whupped," just like the Negro would say "whupped."

div2.head: Gout
div2.u: Mr. Faulkner, what is a "gout"? A "gout" of mud, or a ?
Or—or a gob
I see. A blob or something of that sort.
That's right. A blob, yes.
Is that used a great deal in Mississippi? It must be, of course.
I've—I've heard that in England.
Have you?
Mmhmm.

div2.head: Shegog's Dialect
div2.u: I wondered, Mr. Faulkner, when the Reverend Shegog talks about the "whelming flood," just what that meant.
The overwhelming.
"Overwhelming flood."

I think that's one of the most interesting passages from the point of view of what happens to speech under the stress of strong emotion. At the beginning of his sermon he speaks very properly and with elegant enunciation and diction.
Then when he warms up.
And at the end, there's an immense difference, I think.
I think "recollection" becomes "ricklickshun." Is that right Mr. Faulkner?
Yes.
And "brethren and sisteren" becomes "breddren en sistuhn."
That's right.

div2.head: Ghy' for Gwine
div2.u: Here's one good pronunciation I'd like to commend Mr. Faulkner for. The old colored woman says, "Stop right whar you is. You ain't never crossed dese steps whilst the Cunnel's here and you ain't ghy' do hit now." And it's spelled G-H-Y-apostrophe. And I've heard that very often. Of course, it's a reduced form of "gwine."
That's right
"You ain't ghyn do it now."

div2.head: Close
div2.u: We've enjoyed being with you for the past fifteen minutes for this chat. There is much more on the subject that we could say, but our time has run out on us again. Joining us around the table today were Mr. Ed Stephenson, Mr. Joseph Blotner, and Mr. Robert Davis, and our special guest for the program was Mr. William Faulkner. This is Atcheson Hench thanking you for joining our discussion and inviting you to listen again next week at this time for another chat on some interesting aspect of the language we speak.

div2.head: Scriptural Influence 1
div2.u: Well, the operation's over.
It's a wonder we didn't get in another one I'd like to ask you about.
I had a good one I— a real one.
We're off the air, fellows.
The Bible one. I meant to ask you, has Bible language had much to do with them. And it's down here at the bottom, and I didn't see it.
That would have been a good question. Shame on you.
Well how about it? Why don't you ask it?
We'll save that for next week then.

div2.head: Sho and Sholly
div2.u: You have Wash say, "Sho, Kernel." Now what would the colonel have said? "Shore." He wouldn't have said "sure".
No, he would have said "shur." There would be a little "r."
Yeah, a little "r" on the end of it.
And with Wash there wouldn't be one.
Well I thought that was your point. "Sho" is without the and the Colonel would have said "shore."
One of the most interesting words I found, I think, is "sholly." When—I notice peace officers very often seem to say that in the books.

div2.head: Scriptural Influence 2
div2.u: What is the answer to that question? Does the Bible English have much influence on I suppose that it did.
Yes. It's the only—only reading a lot of them do. And it's the only speech delivered by one— individual.

div2.head: Close
div2.u: He's going to play it over for us. You don't have time, I'm sure.
No, I don't know that we'd be interested in hearing it—would you?
No, you don't care for it.
I want to hear.
Mr. Faulkner, I—
